xxl.core.functions
Class Function<P,R>

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.functions.Function<P,R>
Type Parameters:
P - the type of the function's parameters.
R - the return type of the function.
All Implemented Interfaces:
Serializable
Direct Known Subclasses:
AbstractRealFunctionFunction, AdaBandKernelDensityEstimatorND, AggregationFunctionFunction, ArrayFactory, Constant, DecoratorArrayFunction, DecoratorFunction, FastMapProjection, For.IntegerIncrement, Identity, Iff, NTuplify, PredicateFunction, Print, Println, Projection, RandomAccessFileQueue.InputStreamFactory, RandomAccessFileQueue.OutputStreamFactory, RealFunctionFunction, SVDProjection, Switch, TemporalObject.MAP_TSO_to_TO, Tuplify
public abstract class Function<P,R>
extends Object
implements Serializable

In Java, there is no direct support for the declaration of functional types and functional variables. This deficiency is eliminated by the class Function. In order to declare a function as an object of class Function, the invoke method has to be overridden. This method accepts both separate input parameters and a typed list holding them. The output of invoke is an object of the given return type. Simplified versions of invoke exists suitable for functions with none, one or two input parameters. It is important to mention that in general only one of the invoke methods has to be overriden. The invocation of a function is then triggered by simply calling invoke.

In combination with the powerful mechanism of anonymous classes, it is also possible to build higher-order functions which is known from functional programming (e. g. Haskel). The method compose shows how to declare a function f which consists of h o (f1,...,fn) where h is a function with n arguments and f1,...,fn are functions with an equal number of arguments. Note that compose provides the declaration of the function and does not execute the function.

Consider for example (see also the main-method) that you are interested in building the function tan which can be build by composing division and (sin, cos). Function div, sin, cos; 

   // Initialization of your functional objects
   ...
   // Declaration of a new function
   Function<Double, Double> tan = div.compose(sin, cos);
   ...
   // Execution of the new function
   tan.invoke(x);

Constructor Detail

Function

public Function()
Method Detail

invoke

public R invoke(List<? extends P> arguments)
         throws RuntimeException
Returns the result of the function as an object of the return type. This method determines arguments.size() and calls the appropriate invoke method (see below). The other invoke methods call this method. This means, that the user either has to override this method or one (!) of the other invoke methods. If null is given as argument invoke((P)null) will be returned meaning invoke(P) is needed to be overriden.

Implementation: 

   if (arguments == null)
       return invoke((P)null);
   switch (arguments.size()) {
       case 0:
           return invoke();
       case 1:
           return invoke(arguments.get(0));
       case 2:
           return invoke(arguments.get(0), arguments.get(1));
       default:
           throw new RuntimeException("R invoke(List<? super P>) has to be overridden! The number of arguments was " + arguments.size() + ".");
   }

Parameters:
arguments - a lsit of the arguments to the function.
Returns:
the function value is returned.
Throws:
RuntimeException - if a list of arguments is given that contains 3 or more arguments and the corresponding method R invoke(List<? extends P>) has not been overridden.

invoke

public R invoke()
Returns the result of the function as an object of the result type.

Implementation: 

   return invoke(new ArrayList<P>(0));

Returns:

invoke

public R invoke(P argument0,
                P argument1)

   return invoke(Arrays.asList(argument0, argument1));

Returns:
the function value is returned

compose

public <T> Function<T,R> compose(Function<? super T,? extends P>... functions)
This method declares a new function h by composing a number of functions f_1,...,f_n with this function g.

Note that the method does not execute the code of the new function h. The invocation of the composed function h is just triggered by a call of its own invoke-method. Then, the input parameters are passed to each given function f_1,...,f_n, and the returned objects are used as the input parameters of the new function h. The invoke method of h returns the final result.

Type Parameters:
T - the type of the composed function's parameters.
Parameters:
functions - the functions to be concatenated with this function.
Returns:
the result of the composition.

main

public static void main(String[] args)
The main method contains some examples to demonstrate the usage and the functionality of this class.

Parameters:
args - array of String arguments. It can be used to submit parameters when the main method is called.
